meanings.definition: To establish or fix deeply in a person's mind or nature.
meanings.sent1: Learning to read at a young age can ingrain a love for books.
meanings.sent2: Repeating positive affirmations can help ingrain a sense of self-worth.
meanings.sent3: Trying to ingrain the alphabet backwards in my mind was a fun challenge.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness was so ingrained in her character, it shone through in everything she did.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's passion for science ingrained a curiosity in her students.

meanings.definition: To implant or fix deeply and firmly, as in the nature or mind.
meanings.sent1: The counselor's advice on self-care can ingrain healthy habits.
meanings.sent2: Practicing gratitude daily can ingrain a positive mindset.
meanings.sent3: Trying to ingrain the importance of flossing in my mind made me giggle.
meanings.sent4: His words of encouragement ingrained hope in her heart.
meanings.sent5: The melody of the song ingrained itself in my memory.

meanings.sent1: The traumatic experience ingrained a fear of heights in him.
meanings.sent2: The mentor's advice ingrained a sense of responsibility in her.
meanings.sent3: Trying to ingrain the recipe for the perfect cake in my mind was a tasty challenge.
meanings.sent4: The beauty of the sunset ingrained a sense of peace in her soul.
meanings.sent5: The wise words of her grandmother ingrained valuable life lessons in her.
